repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Second Broad-Based Growth
            Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the El Salvador Second
            Broad-Based Growth Development Policy Loan Project (DPL II)
            were as follows: Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also rated satisfactory. The factor
            leading to the cancellation of the project was the
            non-ratification of the loan by the national assembly of El
            Salvador, and not due to weak implementation or reversal of
            the policy reforms supported by the loan. The DPL II project
            was approved by the Board on December 13, 2005 and the loan
            agreement was signed on March 15, 2007. Subsequently, in
            various sessions, the loan was presented to, and discussed
            by, the national assembly of El Salvador, but due to the
            political gridlock, the loan was never ratified within the
            18 months deadline after Board approval. As a result, the
            Bank terminated the loan agreement as of June 13, 2007. Some
            of the lessons learned from the project are: (i) Bank
            operations are planned and prepared with the Executive
            branch of the Government and the Legislative branch is never
            informed nor consulted during the process of project
            preparation. While this is a good approach to ensure prompt
            project preparation, the fact that loans could end up
            trapped in congress due to political reasons is increasingly
            present. Just like it is done during Country Assistance
            Strategy (CAS) preparation and in coordination with main
            government counterparts, a project level consultation
            process should take place at the congressional level making
            sure that relevant views are received and, if technically
            appropriate for the project, taken into account. At the very
            least, such an approach would convey the message that the
            Bank is an objective, technical player, ready to work with
            any given Government as long as the common goals of poverty
            reduction are pursued as well; (ii) One broad lesson learned
            to reflect on is the changing socio-political environment in
            Latin America. The region is today characterized by an
            increasingly polarized political environment. The Bank
            continues to have a role to play in this context; however,
            it needs to define a strategy to work with clients across
            the political and ideological spectrum existent in Latin
            America today.

abstracts.cdata!:
El Salvador is a lower-middle-income
            country with a remarkable record of structural reforms that
            have resulted in major benefits in terms of macroeconomic
            stability, improved social conditions, trade liberalization,
            and access to international markets. However, a series of
            external factors (the fall in coffee prices, the
            international crisis, the impact of the 2001 earthquakes
            and, more recently, and the rise in oil prices) slowed down
            the countrys economic growth and progress on social
            indicators during 2000-2005. Despite El Salvadors
            accomplishments, the World Banks poverty assessment for the
            country concludes that most of the progress on poverty
            reduction and social indicators has been maintained, but an
            additional boost is needed to continue improvements.
            Consequently, in 2004 the Government of El Salvador adopted
            its Safe Country 2004-2009 program focusing on greater
            economic growth, sound fiscal management, and public sector
            modernization. The plan requires that a policy and
            investment agenda be implemented to reinvigorate economic
            growth through job creation and poverty reduction, together
            with efforts to redirect fiscal trends and make greater
            financial management improvements.

repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Second Broad-Based Growth
            Development Policy Loan (DPL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Broad-Based Growth Development
            Policy Loan (DPL) constitutes the second project in a
            programmatic series of up to four DPLs, to support the
            Government's medium term development strategy in
            accelerating broad based, and equitable economic growth, and
            in contributing to the Government's objectives of
            reigniting growth, particularly through increased private
            investment and trade, reinforcing macroeconomic stability
            and strengthening fiscal sustainability, and, increasing the
            efficiency and transparency of public sector management.
            This second operation builds on the first operation, and
            focuses on addressing fiscal issues, and on strengthening
            the international trade and business environment, for which
            it will draw on findings set forth in the Country Economic
            Memorandum (CEM), Public Expenditure Review (PER), Dominican
            Republic-Central America Free Trade Agreement with the
            United States of America (DR-CAFTA) studies, as well as the
            Investment Climate Assessment. It will likewise continue to
            emphasize transparency, and efficiency in public spending by
            including follow up actions on public financial management,
            and procurement regulations to ensure the gradual
            implementation of measures as prescribed in the Country
            Financial Accountability Assessment (CFAA) and Country
            Procurement Assessment Report (CPAR). Nonetheless, risks
            exist, such as fiscal, political, external - i.e., sustained
            high oil prices or a new international recession, could
            negatively affect El Salvador's economy and worsen debt
            dynamics - as well as natural disasters, and crime and violence.
